Statement: Alliance with the vanara (monkey) army was instrumental in Rama’s victory over Lanka.
Bharata accepted the throne without any longing for Rama’s return.
Bharata declared war on Rama immediately after his exile.
Bharata was the youngest of Rama’s brothers.
Dasaratha wanted Lakshmana to become the kind of Ayodhya.
Dasaratha was still alive when Rama returned to Ayodhya after the exile.
Dasharatha performs a Putrakameshti yajna to beget sons.
Demoness Shurpanakha played a pivotal role in inciting the conflict between Rama and Ravana.
Demoness Simhika tries to capture Hanuman during his flight but is killed by him.
Dushana was the king of monkeys allied to Ravana.
Hanuman betrayed Rama by divulging his battle plans to Ravana.
Hanuman is born to Anjana and Kesari with blessings from the wind god, Vayu.
Hanuman married Surasa, the serpent goddess.
Hanuman never meets Sita in the entire epic.
Hanuman was defeated by Sita in a contest of strength during their first meeting.
Hanuman was taught the scriptures by Sage Surasa during his journey to Lanka.
Hanuman’s leap to Lanka was achieved by riding a golden chariot rather than by his own power.
Jatayu survived after fighting Ravana and later guided Rama to Sita.
Jatayu tries to rescue Sita from Ravana and is mortally wounded.
Kumbhakarna sleeps for six months at a time.
Kumbhakarna was Ravana’s father.
Lakshmana betrayed Rama by siding with Ravana during the war.
Lakshmana is famous for his love of music and poetry rather than his loyalty to Rama.
Lakshmana refused to accompany Rama into exile and stayed in Ayodhya.
Lakshmana was not related to Rama but was merely an adopted son with no real bond.
Malyavan was Ravana’s son who betrayed him.
Malyavan, a rakshasa commander, advised Ravana to return Sita to avoid disaster.
Mandavi, Bharata’s wife, is the daughter of King Kushadhvaja.
Mandodari, Ravana’s queen, is portrayed as a noble and wise figure despite her husband’s deeds.
Rama breaks Shiva’s bow to win Sita’s hand in marriage.
Rama is described as having a golden complexion in his youth.
Rama is frequently depicted riding a tiger instead of driving a chariot.
Rama is known for his uncontrollable temper and unruly behavior.
Rama is often depicted holding a bow and arrow, representing his warrior spirit.
Rama kills the demoness Tataka in the forest.
Rama refused to go into exile despite his father’s explicit orders.
Rama uses the Brahmastra to kill Ravana.
Rama was born in Lanka and later moved to Ayodhya.
Rama’s departure for exile brought great sorrow to the people of Ayodhya.
Rama’s exile lasted for fourteen years, as decreed by his stepmother Kaikeyi.
Rama’s journey to Lanka was undertaken in a hot air balloon instead of by a constructed bridge.
Rama’s reign is idealized as an era of peace and prosperity, often referred to as Rama Rajya.
Rama’s victory over Ravana symbolizes the triumph of dharma (righteousness) over adharma (unrighteousness).
Ramayana emphasizes the importance of following dharma over personal desires.
Ramayana is traditionally divided into six books, known as Kandas.
Ramayana was composed by the sage Valmiki, earning him the title of Adikavi (the first poet).
Ravana is depicted as both a formidable warrior and a learned scholar in the Ramayana.
Ravana is portrayed as a kind and gentle ruler throughout the Ramayana.
Ravana is traditionally depicted with ten heads, symbolizing his vast knowledge and pride.
Ravana voluntarily returned Sita to Rama out of sudden remorse without any conflict.
Ravana was a demon (rakshasa) by birth.
Ravana was defeated without any battle or struggle in the Ramayana.
Ravana was undefeatable because he had a magical armor.
Ravana’s son Indrajit uses magical weapons in battle.
Sage Agastya blessed Rama during his early adventures, guiding his journey.
Shatrughna is Rama's youngest brother.
Shurpanakha tries to seduce Rama and Lakshmana but is disfigured by Lakshmana.
Sita accompanied Rama into exile, symbolizing her unwavering loyalty.
Sita cursed Ravana to be reborn as a demon again.
Sita is described as having magical powers that allowed her to summon storms.
Sita is found by King Janaka while he is ploughing the field.
Sita is portrayed as a warrior who fought against Ravana on the battlefield.
Sita left Rama willingly to live in Lanka.
Sita was never abducted; she voluntarily went to Lanka.
Sita was the biological daughter of Ravana.
Sita’s abduction by Ravana led to the unification of various forces against the demon king.
Sugreeva defeats Bali in a fist fight.
Sugreeva, the monkey king, became a trusted ally of Rama against the forces of Lanka.
Sugriva becomes king of Kishkindha with Rama’s help.
Sugriva was hesitant to trust Rama until Rama helped him defeat Vali.
Sumantra was a warrior who fought bravely in Lanka’s army.
The monkey army in the Ramayana was led by Ravana himself.
The monkey warrior Nala was an architect who helped build the Rama Setu (bridge).
The vulture Sampati aided Hanuman by providing crucial information during his journey.
Trijata comforts Sita during her captivity through prophetic dreams.
Vali is killed by Rama from behind while fighting Sugriva.
Valmiki composed the Ramayana while exiled on a deserted island with no guidance.
Valmiki was a warrior king who fought alongside Rama in battle.
Vibhisana was killed in the war between Rama and Ravana.
Vibhishana, Ravana’s brother, defected to Rama’s side due to his commitment to righteousness.
